creator: kenneth.russell@sun.com
text:
The nested exclude tag supported by the javac task is broken when passed a
comma-separated set of files or directories. The test case at
http://www.rawbw.com/~kbrussel/anttest.zip illustrates the problem. Note that
the default "all" target pretty obviously should not be compiling either B.java
or C.java. In fact, if you delete C.java from the source tree and remove the
"b/c/**" portion of the exclude tag, B.java will be properly excluded from the
compile.

Using the excludes parameter instead of the nested exclude tag works correctly.
See the "aonly" target in the test case's build.xml.

This bug is present both in the current Ant 1.6.5 as well as in the 1.7.0 beta
2. I filed this as "major" severity given that javac is very much a core Ant
task and this took a while to track down.

text: AFAIK nested include/exclude elements have NEVER supported comma-seperated lists.

Kenneth.

this isnt a bug. This is an explicit feature of all filesets.

includes= and excludes= are shorthand for providing a list of includes/excludes,
but have some limitations, most specifically, there's no way to use a ',' in any
of the filenames you want to include or exclude.

the include/exclude nested fileset elements take one pattern only. If you want
more than one pattern, you need to have multiple <include>/<exclude> elements. 

It sounds like this cost you some time, and for that I'm sorry. Remember, the
user@ant.apache.org mailing list is the place to come for help. 

Marking as invalid.
